And if you'd pray for that, I know they'd appreciate it. Psalm chapter number three, and we'll be looking at verses seven and eight this evening. Back on the 1st of December, the first week of December, we started a mini-series through this psalm, Psalm chapter number three. And on the first six verses, we took two verses a week. And during those first three lessons, as we looked at this psalm, we discovered the reality of the situation in verses one and two. In verses three and four, we discovered the response of David to the situation. And then in verses five and six, we looked at the rest of David and how that he rested in the Lord. Notice in verse number one, the Bible says, "'Lord, how are they increased that trouble me? "'Many are they that rise up against me, "'many there be which say of my soul, "'there is no help for him in God, Selah.'" This was the reality of the situation that David was facing. We know that the Bible teaches us, and as we look at contextually what's going on, you look back and you can find that really the setting of this particular psalm is believed to be that of the revolt, the rebellion and revolt of Absalom. And you can read of that in 2 Samuel chapters 15 through 19. And you see that it was a serious situation. David was not exaggerating the circumstances. He was not just pretending that this was some difficulty. This was a serious situation in which he was dealing with. And we noted the reality of the situation. We said that the response to the situation was noteworthy and exemplary. You find it in verses three and four. Notice what David says as he responds to the situation, "'But thou, O Lord, art a shield for me.'" Remember, they were saying there is no help for him in God, Selah. But David says, "'I understand, God, that you are a shield for me, "'my glory and the lifter up of mine head.'" Notice what he says in verse number four, "'I cried unto the Lord with my voice, "'and he heard me out of his holy hill, Selah.'" Isn't that a great response to such a difficult situation? And we find that it's important for us to understand the response of David and understand that we too should respond in like fashion when we deal with difficulty and adversity and troubles and trials, how we cry to the Lord, how we trust in God and depend upon him. And after we pour out our heart to God, after we carry our burdens to the Lord, knowing that he cares for us, we find that we can have a great rest, a great peace that passeth all understanding. And that's what we see in verses five and six. Notice the Bible says, "'I laid me down and slept. "'I awaked, for the Lord sustained me. "'I will not be afraid of 10,000s of people "'that have set themselves against me roundabout.'" Why? Because he's trusting in the Lord and he's taken his burden to the Lord and he's laid it. The Bible tells us, "'Cast thy burden upon the Lord. "'He will sustain thee.'" Knowing that we're to cast all of our care upon him. Why? "'For he careth for us, he careth for you.'" And what great truth that is. And we find here in verses five and six, this great peace and this rest that David experiences. And how in our lives, when we deal with troubles and trials and difficulties, we respond to those by going to God and then we can rest knowing that God is able. And what great truth that is and how important it is that we understand that rest that is possible for us. This evening, as we look at verses seven and eight, we will note the rejoicing of David. I've used for the title, the first phrase in verse number eight, "'Salvation belongeth unto the Lord.'" But if you're kind of taking notes for each of these lessons and really looking at the four divisions of Psalm three, the rejoicing of David is what is in focus this evening. Notice in verse number seven, the Bible says, "'Arise, O Lord, save me, O my God. "'For thou hast smitten all mine enemies upon the cheekbone. "'Thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly. "'Salvation belongeth unto the Lord. "'Thy blessing is upon thy people, Selah.'" So we note the rejoicing and we think about the rejoicing of David as it's seen in verses seven and eight. I wanna emphasize just for a moment by way of introduction this evening, the importance of praise in the life of a believer. We understand that we have many reasons to rejoice. The Bible tells us in Psalm 118 and verse number 24, in fact, we sing the song often, this is the day the Lord hath made. We will what? Rejoice in it, right? And be glad. And you think about that rejoicing, understanding that God has planned, that God has purpose, that God is in control. And we're gonna rejoice understanding who God is. Think about that great truth that is given in Philippians chapter number four and verse number four. Rejoice in the Lord, how often? All way, right? Though he says rejoice in the Lord all way, again, I say rejoice. Well, that's impactful. It's pretty plain, is it not? Rejoice in the Lord all way. And again, I say rejoice. You know, as human beings, we could identify and understand there are times in which it seems to be a little bit easier to rejoice in our particular circumstances and situations. But God tells us to rejoice in the Lord all way. And again, I say rejoice. Giving thanks always for all things. That's all-inclusive. And that's the instruction that's been given to us as the people of God. We find it in 1 Thessalonians 5 and verse number 16. The Bible says this, rejoice evermore. Simple, rejoice evermore. And really, it's a mindset, it's a purpose that we have in our lives that we are going to purpose to rejoice. And we are going to look for, in every circumstance, in every situation, we're gonna find reason to rejoice. Where's my coat? And so I came over to my office, I looked in my office, it's not my office, I went to the fellowship hall, I looked all over the place, can't find my coat. And I said, you know what, I bet you my mom grabbed it by accident. So I called my mom, mom, do you have my coat? She's like, I don't know. Finds it, yep, here it is. And I said, well, I'm on my way. He's resting in God, and now he is rejoicing. The first phrase in verse number seven of our study this evening confirms for us two truths that we find throughout the entirety of the Psalm. Notice the first phrase here in verse number seven. Arise, O Lord, save me, O my God. I believe that in this statement that the two truths that are confirmed to us are this, number one, David is confident in the Lord. He is confident in the ability of God and the power of the Lord to save him. He is confident. He is convinced that God is able, and I believe he has that full confidence. And we need to have confidence in God as we live life, as we go through this journey, as we deal with difficulties and adversities, that we can have confidence in knowing that our God is able, that there's nothing that's too hard for him, that there's no trial, no situation, no circumstance that's beyond his ability, and we need to understand that we. are to be confident in him. I believe the second truth that is revealed to us in this statement to begin verse number seven is that David is dependent upon the Lord. Notice he says, arise, O Lord, save me, O my God. The personal relationship is there, obviously. He says, O my God, the personal understanding. But you find that he's dependent upon the Lord. He's trusting that God, he is confident in God's ability, but he's fully dependent on God to work. And how we need to depend upon God, trust in him wholly and completely, and you find that he is wholly true. And he is trustworthy, and we ought to rejoice in that. Now look at the rejoicing. Notice the remainder of verse number seven. Notice this, the Bible says, for thou hast smitten all mine enemies upon the cheekbone. Thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly. I want you to notice the phrase that is repeated twice in this portion of verse number seven. Notice the Bible says, thou hast. And when you see that phrase, he says, thou hast smitten all mine enemies upon the cheekbone. Thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly. What we find is that David is rejoicing, and we find that what God has done for us, and that which he has done on our behalf, should cause us to rejoice. When we look back and we remember the blessings of God, we remember the working of God, and we find that David here is looking back and he's remembering what God has done. Thou hast done these things. And in Psalm 77 in verse number 10, the Bible says this, and I said, this is my infirmity, but I will remember the years of the right hand of the Most High. I will remember the works of the Lord. Surely I will remember thy wonders of old. I will meditate also of all thy work and talk of thy doings. You know, it's a good thing for us to remember what God has done. And as we remember what God has done, it should cause us to rejoice. Because we're acknowledging, we're meditating upon, we're remembering, we're rehearsing those things in our mind, and he says, thou hast smitten all mine enemies upon the cheekbone. Thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly. And I find that David is rejoicing here, and he's rejoicing because God has worked. Not only should the recollection of God's working and the remembrance that is mentioned here for, he's speaking of those past victories and the past working of God, not only should that cause us to rejoice, but I believe this evening that it should cause us to trust God in our current situation. Think about the rehearsing. Think about what he's remembering. It's just summarized in two statements. Thou hast smitten all mine enemies upon the cheekbone. Thou hast broken the teeth of the ungodly. But as David is the one that is penning this psalm, as he's recalling and remembering, you think about the floods of memories that would permeate his mind as he's writing these words, and he's mindful of what God has done, which will result in the rejoicing, but it also leads to trusting, because if God was able to do it before, then he's able to do it now, right? God doesn't change. He's the same yesterday and today and forever, and we find here that David is rejoicing, but through the rejoicing as he set his mind, remember I said this, we must purpose to rejoice. This is the day the Lord hath made. We will rejoice and be glad in it. Rejoice in the Lord always, and again I say rejoice, rejoice evermore. When I purpose to rejoice, all of a sudden, what's happening is my focus and my attention is Godward, instead of on my problem, instead of on my situation, and what we find is that God is greater than any situation that we face. What happens so often in our lives is that we have so much of our focus and so much of our attention upon our problem, and our problem just continues to grow and grow and grow, and we're just so focused upon our problem that we're not rejoicing as we see David doing here, and therefore our attention is not Godward. We're just so focused on whatever the problem at hand is. We mentioned that in the response in verses three and four when he responded by praising the Lord, thanking God for who he is, and declaring his dependence upon God in verses three and four, and as we noted that in that study a few weeks ago, we understood that that too is how we should respond, and when we respond in that fashion, our attention is upon the Lord. The more we focus on a problem, the bigger the problem becomes. It just can consume us, and we find here that his attention is Godward. Why? Because he's rejoicing, because he's praising God for what he, God, has done on his behalf. Notice in verse number eight that David recognizes that salvation belongeth unto the Lord. This here, as you often find in the Old Testament, especially in the Book of Psalms, the term salvation is not the same use of the word that we would use in New Testament Christianity of being saved, being born again, but it's a word that is often used to simply deal with deliverance. Now, we understand when we speak of our salvation that we're speaking about our deliverance from the penalty of sin, and here, in many other areas in the Book of Psalms, when you read the salvation that is being discussed, he's speaking about the deliverance that God has provided, such as what he has mentioned in verse number seven, where God had smitten all his enemies and broken the teeth of the ungodly, and notice the recognition here. The very truth of this recognition that salvation or deliverance belongs to God would cause us to rejoice. It's not in my power, it's not in my ability to provide deliverance. It's not up to me to come up with the plan for deliverance. You think about the life of David, and you think about the many victories, the triumphs of David as you read throughout his life. Remember, this is near the end of his life. This is during the time of the rebellion and revolt of Absalom, and you think about all that has taken place prior to that in the life of David, and you read of all of his triumphs and all of the victories, and as you begin to fill your mind with recalling those great things that are recorded in 1 and 2 Samuel, and reading of all of those great victories, you find that David, as he makes the statement, salvation belongeth unto the Lord, that just the recognition of that truth would lead to rejoicing, thanking God that he is our deliverer, that he is the one that provides deliverance. David fought many times against the Philistines, and it started, of course, we understand, in that great battle against Goliath, and we're familiar with 1 Samuel in chapter number 17, and we look at that passage of Scripture, and it's a very prominent portion of Scripture, and one in which we find just great encouragement, and the reality is that when David goes to fight against Goliath, he was not depending upon himself. When Saul tries to give him the armor and all that he tries to give him, David understands that, listen, salvation belongeth unto the Lord. He understood that it was God that had delivered him previously, and that it was God that would fight on his behalf. There were times in which he fought the Philistines, and there were times in which the Philistines invaded cities, and David would seek the face of God. And God would answer, and God would provide direction, and as he was depending upon the Lord, he understood that it was the Lord that brought the deliverance. Salvation belongeth unto the Lord. I'm thankful for the many blessings that He's bestowed upon us. We sing songs about count your blessings, name them one by one. And I want you to understand that as David is remembering the fact that God is blessing and that His blessing is upon His people, we must be mindful of this truth this evening that God's blessings come in different forms and at different times. There can be something in our life that's a blessing and sometimes we don't really look at it as being a blessing because we just have a wrong perspective because we think that a blessing is something that is defined by our finite ability to describe or to define what a blessing is, but the reality is that in God's infinite wisdom and in His mercy, He gives blessings to His people and there are times in which we may not even recognize things as being blessings. When Joseph revealed himself to his brothers, he tells them, God sent me before you to preserve life. And Joseph says, yes, you meant it for evil, but God meant it for good to save much people alive. Man, can you imagine? In fact, as you look at the life of Joseph and you understand what's taking place there and you see how God was working, it's very challenging for us in the midst of the situation to understand all that's taking place.
